Parker Willis to Carter Glass, presenting his thinking with respect to the recommendations of Goldenweiser and Burgess. The points at which the Carter Glass bill should be strengthened are listed. Plea for resolution of conflicts with respect to certain basic points is made by H. Parker Willis; H. Parker Willis requests $5,000 for his services as expert to the Senate sub-committee; Letter, April 18, 1932, to Carter Glass, H. Parker Willis expresses the desire to have a copy of a memorandum on the Glass bill prepared by Morgan and Company; Tentative suggestion by Carter Glass in a letter of April 25, 1932, that H. Parker Willis be present when the Senate considers the banking bill; Letter, March 21, 1932, from Carter Glass, stating that it is imperative that H. Parker Willis be present for the hearings on the banking bill; Letter, March 28, 1932, from H. Parker Willis to Carter Glass stating that, when the hearings were over, he would study them, make a list of the specific suggestions included, and present them to Carter Glass for his approval or disapproval; Letter of March 22, 1932, from Edmond E. Lincoln, of duPont, to H. Parker Willis, mentioning the difficulty enforcement of certain provisions of the Carter Glass bill and the attribution of too much power to the Federal Reserve Board; Included in an analysis of the provisions of the Carter Glass bill prepared confidentiality by Lincoln; Letter to H. Parker Willis from Carter Glass, April 19, 1932, training the legislative history of the banking bill up to the moment and entering complaints about the thinking of members of the Federal Reserve Board and the poor record of the New York Reserve Bank; Carter Glass sent H. Parker Willis a copy of a report by Governor Harrison and also requests an opinion on certain amendments concerning reserves to the Federal Reserve Act; Letter Carter Glass to H. Parker Willis, January 9, 1932, regarding the prevention of evidences of debt from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation being made eligible for discount and expressing the opinion that only technical changes should be made in the bill; Letter to Carter Glass from H. Parker Willis, January 22, 1932, refuting the charges the H. Parker Willis, in attacking the newly adopted policy of inflation, had caused a loss of confidence among foreigners in the dollar; Letter from H. Parker Willis, requesting a copy of the social security Act from Rixey Smith; Letter, July 29, 1935, from H. Parker Willis to Rixey Smith, stating that the Carter Glass bill was meeting with a better reception that he had anticipated. He requests copies of the final draft, Carter Glass' speech on the bill, etc. to facilitate the writing of an article; H. Parker Willis, May 22, 1935, requests Rixey Smith to send him a copy of Marriner Eccles testimony before the House, preparatory to his own appearance before the Senate Committee; Letter, May 20, 1935, H. Parker Willis expresses the opinion that things have progressed in such a way that his services are unnecessary and he does not feel and compelling need for testifying before the Committee; In answer to a request from Parker H. Parker Willis to make a speech at Columbia, Carter Glass says he plans to turn his attention to the wrecking of the Marriner Eccles bill and Eccles too, if possible; Letter, December 17, 1932, from H. Parker Willis, attempting to arrange a meeting with Carter Glass about the banking bill; Correspondence during March, 1933, wherein H. Parker Willis reminds Carter Glass that he is to recommend Willis as United States representative to the World Economic Conference and Glass makes the suggestion to Cordell Hull, Secretary of State; Letters from H. Parker Willis returning borrowed material to Carter Glass; Note from J. F. T. O'Connor, Comptroller of the Currency, October 10, 1933, pointing out the critical attitude of H. Parker Willis toward the financial policies of the administration and enclosing a report, stating that H. Parker Willis felt that the banking system needed reconsideration; Communications concerning the repercussion in foreign countries of H. Parker Willis ' report of inflationary tendencies among high officials; Letter, June 18, 1932,, from H. Parker Willis to Carter Glass, in which H. Parker Willis expresses the hope that, although action on the Carter Glass bill has been postponed, its enemies have not been able to shelve it completely; H. Parker Willis sends copies of two possible changes in the Federal Reserve Act on October 23, 1932; December 2, 1932, Carter Glass writes to H. Parker Willis that questions relating to branch banking are holding up the Carter Glass bill; Letters from Carter Glass to H. Parker Willis, December, 1932, trying to get him to Washington to participate in committee consideration of the Carter Glass bill; Copy of the Congressional Record, in which H. Parker Willis ' problems with the State Department are aired; Paper, "Analysis of the Proposal for Devaluation of the Dollar."

A. Miscellaneous correspondence of the period, including personal letter: Letter from Senator Harry F. Byrd stating that he enjoyed a chat with Carter Glass; Letter from Alva B. Adams, chairman of the Public Lands and Surveys Committee, thanking Carter Glass for congratulatory note on his re-election; Letter from Carter Glass to Harry F. Byrd in which he states, "This whole New Deal program simply amounts to political corruption by misuse of taxpayers money"; Important letter from Carter Glass to Leo Crowley of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, roundly criticizing Marriner Eccles about a proposed reorganization of the banking system; Letters remarking about the attack made by Carter Glass on Colonel House in his book; a copy of an article on distribution of income reprinted from the Quarterly Journal of Economics, sent by the General Motors Corporation, whose employee wrote the article; Statement regarding the connection of Carter Glass with the attempt to make Woodrow Wilson the first president of the University of Virginia. (See envelope in this box); Expression of the idea by Carter Glass that Huey Long was the one responsible for the idea of curtailing production so as to raise prices, thereby ending a depression. Long's statement on cotton production cited. Carter Glass records opposition to the policy, which was later adopted. He opposed the AAA and National Recovery Administration; Telegram from the Secretary of the Senate, September 13, 1939, informing Carter Glass of the calling of an extra session of Congress; Copy of a Franklin D. Roosevelt speech promising to stop deficit financing, sent to Carter Glass by a bitter insurance executive; Letter blaming bankers attitudes for the withholding of money from circulation. Carter Glass responds that the reason is that "no one knows today what his dollar will be worth tomorrow"; List of the accomplishments of the public works projects of the federal government in Virginia. Carter Glass answers that the taxpayers consent should have been gotten and the state should have done the work; Editorial supporting Senator George for renomination and listing Carter Glass as a truly loyal Democrat, opposing the "liberal" theories espoused by Franklin D. Roosevelt; Carter Glass, in answer to a letter, states that Governor Price of Virginia was one of the worst of governors; Preliminary expressions of doubt as to the advisability of a third term for Franklin D. Roosevelt; Twelve page paper by William F. Russell of Columbia University on communism and the way to meet its menace; Carter Glass states, in answer to a letter, that he opposed the 1938 Appropriations bill as being too large, although he was chairman of the Appropriations Committee; Letters opposing the granting of further powers to the Federal Home Loan Board, particularly in regard to the chartering of federal savings and loan associations; Request from the Union Trust Company of Maryland that changes be made in the plan of the Federal Reserve Board to end the practice of interlocking directorates; Letter from W. G. McAdoo, inquiring as to the advisability of moving his family to Charlottesville; Telegram of November 10, 1938, from Carter Glass congratulating Pat McCarron on his re-election to the Senate, and the Senator's expression of appreciation; In answer to a letter from James E. Palmer, Carter Glass favorably notes W. A. Scott's repudiation of the book by Garrison on Franklin D. Roosevelt, Wilson, et. al. Carter Glass also mentions many communications from Paul M. Warburg attributing to Carter Glass authorship of the Federal Reserve Act; Editorial citing Edmund Platt's attitude toward restraining credit early in 1929, while he was on the Federal Reserve Board and his subsequent opposition to the abandonment of the gold standard; Letter of December 2, 1938, from Edmund Platt, expressing his agreement with Carter Glass on the "gradual destruction of the Federal Reserve System " and recalling his attacks on "the monetary magicians"; Letter from Edmund Platt to Carter Glass, pointing out the failure of the Federal Reserve System to serve as a commercial system because of its cheap money policy and the devaluation of the dollar. It is also stated that a check on the cheap money policy might develop, if bank deposits continue to increase, while interest rates remain low, and capital accounts continue to be difficult to increase; Carter Glass replying that the Federal Reserve System is being ruined by the presidential appointee at the head of the Board into a central bank is noted; Letter, November 17, 1938, to James E. Palmer, in which Carter Glass recalls having denounced the author, Garrison, but search of his records failed to reveal the attack; Correspondence by which Carter Glass forces correction of a newspaper story, stating that he Palmer biography of him was "authorized" by Carter Glass; Letter from Edmund Platt, citing a report by George W. Dowrie favoring the extension of branch banking even in opposition to state laws. Edmund Platt agrees with Dowrie and feels that Carter Glass probably does too; Letter criticizing Federal Housing Administration methods of rejecting an applicant as a credit risk and suggesting limitation of the powers of Federal Housing Administration authorities; Letter from A. Willis Robertson, a member of the House of Representatives, to Carter Glass, concerning appropriations for the Blue Ridge Parkway; Letters relating to the biographies being prepared simultaneously by Palmer and Messrs. Smith and Beasley, including letters from Carter Glass to Rixey Smith, while he was working on the collection here being examined. ( Carter Glass states that he never listened to lobbyists); Letter from Rixey Smith approving the condemnation of Harold L. Ickes by Carter Glass, after Harold L. Ickes attack; a letter expressing the opinion that the result of unemployment compensation grants is to encourage idleness is answered by Carter Glass with a statement of the stupidity of a government agency attempting to control the affairs of private business. Carter Glass recommends the abolition of the New Deal agencies; Correspondence congratulating Millard E. Tydings on his victory against administration forces in winning re-election to the Senate; Address "Recent Economic Trends," by Representative Woodrum, July 6, 1938.

A. Letters, telegrams, etc. in regard to legislation under consideration at the time: Letters relating to proposed amendments to the National Labor Relations Act; Opposition expressed to LaFollette bill; Correspondence giving views on the situation in Europe; Aid to Allies favored; Favor expressed for Walter-Logan bill by many correspondents; Opposition expressed to attempt to give the government title to submerged land off the coast; Repeal of the Johnson Act requested; Opposition to the Wheeler-Jones bill; Support for the Maloney bill, relating to the sugar industry asked; Aid for Poland supported; Support asked for the Gillette-Kleberg bill; Opposition to a bill permitting the establishment of branch banks across state lines; Letter from Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administration administrator, reporting on the work of his agency in Virginia during 1939; Letters opposing proposed changes in the organization of the Works Progress Administration; Approval expressed of the Barden amendments to the Wage-Hour Law; Favor expressed for the bill in the House to restrain chain stores in their exertion of monopoly powers; Report of the Senate Commerce Committee on the River and Harbor bill, April 3, 1940.

A. Letters, telegrams, etc. dealing with legislative matters under consideration: Letters urging careful consideration to the war situation in Europe, repeal of the Johnson and Neutrality Acts requested; Letters supporting Carter Glass stand in favor of sending supplies to the Allies to combat German aggression; Letters expressing opposition to the LaFollette Civil Liberties Bill; Letter from the president of the Dairymen's League, favoring legislation encouraging a sound credit system (reasonable level of prices) rather than a lowering of interest rates; Letter protesting the statement of the Department of Labor that lumber retailers were wholesalers; Letters, pro and con, concerning the Smith amendments to the Wagner Labor Relations Act; Letters and statements relating to the National Economy League, strongly opposing continued expenditures for luxury items by the government, if defense expenses continued; Many letters suggesting that Congress remain in session in order to provide for the nation's defense; Letter, June 14, 1940, from M. F. Brennan, president of the United Mine Workers, opposing the Smith amendment; Letters encouraging the continuation of freight forwarding services; Letter to Carter Glass from the chairman of the House Rules Committee, enclosing a copy of a letter from Representative Hoffman to his Republican colleagues attacking President Franklin D. Roosevelt; Requests for support of the Truman-Hobbes bill on transportation; Telegrams, May 16, 1940, requesting support for the President's talk on defense; Letters opposing the Jones-Wheeler bill; Questions raised in regard to a proposed law as to whether certain investments of trust companies would be exempt from specific regulations. Changes proposed; Question from a Democrat as to how to vote in 1940, if he could not support a further administration spending program; Letter from a clearing house association opposing the establishment of branch banks across state lines; Requests that the Truman-Hobbes bill be passed over the President's veto; Three petitions urging opposition to the Lee bill; Suggestion of a retail sales tax made by a lawyer; Letters, May, 1940, asking that Works Progress Administration workers not be reclassified and paid less; Correspondence from industrial concerns opposing the LaFollette bill; Support requested for the Logan-Walter bill; Form letter to the Senators from James M. Meade of the Commerce Committee, suggesting an amendment to the Federal Reserve Act which would be designed to enlarge the credit opportunities for small businesses; Copy of Frederick A. Delano's proposal for a "sound economic monetary system for the United States " (8 pages) accompanied by a request for criticism; Letter from Senator Bilbo of the Agricultural and Forestry Committee with several enclosures relating to types of covering for bales of cotton.

A. Letter from Blakey, President of the National Bank of Burlington opposing giving Comptroller of the Currency power to pass on dividends of National Banks; a thesis "Win the War with Gold" by Marvin and Heath; Letter from Citizens Bank of Fairmount regarding banks with branches; Many letters opposing the Smith Bill amending National Recovery Administration (Wagner Act); Many letters opposing adjournment of Congress; Many letters urging help for Finland; Many letters urging help for Britain; Many letters of opposition to entering the war.

A. Harry F. Byrd reports on non-essential government spending of which Committee Carter Glass was a member and discusses monetary policy; Paper by Frederick A. Delano, an uncle of the President and later Comptroller of the Currency; Most items relate to national defense.

A. Correspondence on various subject under legislative consideration at the time: Papers protesting further government infringement upon the life insurance business; Letter protesting further shipments of materials to Japan, which aid her in the war against China; Pleas to insure the retaining of a 3 1/2% interest rate on mortgages held by the Federal Land Banks; Letter from a banker, having to do with bank loans to officers; Aid to Finland requested; Letter questioning the possibility of a repudiation of the national debt; Letters supporting or expressing opposition to proposed changes in the Wage and Hour Law; Suggested amendments to the Fair Labor Standard Act; pamphlet stating reasons for opposing the St. Lawrence Seaway; Suggestion from Illinois Manufacturers' Association that the National Labor Relations Act be repealed, or at least changed in stated respects.

A. List of the ideas of the Transportation Association of America, concerning governmental policies toward the railroads; Letters concerning excise taxes on tobacco; Expression of opposition to the proposed Federal Mine Inspection Bill; Letters expressing appreciation to Carter Glass for introducing a bill in the Senate against interlocking bank directorates' Pamphlet concerning dentistry and the National Health Program; Letter from the Campana Sales Company, protesting a demand by the Federal Trade Commission for information concerning the financial operations of the business; Letters favoring the Wheeler-Truman bill, concerning transportation; Letter, January 24, 1940, protesting the unreasonably high capital requirements for banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System and also want to establish branches; Letter favoring the Kindergarten Bill; Cotton interests request extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements; Letter from a member bank of the Federal Reserve System, criticizing the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for taking so long to answer vital correspondence; Letters and telegrams, concerning a British embargo on American tobacco, including communications from Cordell Hull at the Department of State; Copy of a bill from the Senate Commerce Committee, regarding public works projects on rivers and harbors; Letter enclosing a statement entered in the Congressional Recordby Senator Harry F. Byrd, dealing in excellent fashion with the low rate of interest on government bonds and its effects; Letters opposing the quota system for states under civil service laws; Letter from a Winchester, Virginia, bank, stating that, contrary to prevalent opinion, there was no lack of credit facilities in 1939.
A. Letters relative to loan to Finland; Japanese aggression in China; Advertising of liquor by radio.

A. Miscellaneous letters, 1940: Letters from a coal mining and shipping firm, relating to proper pricing of coal; Letters opposing the use of radio for liquor advertisements; Letter favoring the exemption of dairy products from compliance with the Federal Wage Hour Law; Letter opposing the continued application of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement to the manganese industry; Attacks on the methods employed in taking the census; Protests concerning the delay in proceeding with the taking of the census; Letter favoring the bill presented by Senator Logan to limit the powers of Federal bureaus; Letter opposing price supports for sugar beet growers; Copy of a resolution by the West Virginia Chamber of Commerce, expressing opposition to the Mead bill, which would set up an Industrial Loan Corporation; Letters requesting continued protection for he sugar industry; Letter stating that gold was being substituted for credit as reserves and that ineligible paper was being discounted; Letter from Blythe W. Branch to Dr. Douglas S. Freeman, March 15, 1940, warning of the danger to America of continued German aggression; Warning of impending danger to America of the fall of Finland; Letters criticizing the Wagner Act and the Fair Labor Standard Act, advocating changes; Letters, pro and con, on legislation to restrain chain store organization; Letter suggesting that more strict mine inspection is intended to do more than insure health and safety; Letter from the Association of Ship Brokers and Agents, opposing the grant of power over coastal waterways to the Interstate Commerce Commission; Letters favoring the maintenance of an independent banking system in preference to a system of branch banking; Editorial in the Columbus Evening Dispatch, April 11, 1940, showing how federal agencies, once established, extend their powers, e. g., the S. E. C.; Memorandum from the Federal Advisory Council advising against adoption of amendments to the Federal Home Loans Bank Act; Letter from Representative Bierman, April 4, 1940, concerning responsibility for the establishment of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation; Letter, April 3, 1940, from Senator Downey, asking Carter Glass to be present when he criticizes the Social Security Act. He said public funds were going to wealthy people, instead of contributions going to needy folks; Letters in regard to amendments to the National Labor Relations Act; Banker opposition to Jones-Wheeler bill; Reports, March 15, 1940, concerning rivers and harbors; Letters relating to the Hull reciprocal trade program; Letter from a farmer, requesting more liberal loan conditions and an extension of parity price plans.

A. Labor legislation: Petitions opposing all anti-labor legislation which were under consideration, e. g., the Smith bill; Several letters having to do with the decision of the War Labor Board in the case involving the Walker-Turner company; Letters specifically favoring or opposing the forty-hour week, the closed shop, overtime pay, etc.; Letters protesting the advantages enjoyed by a laborer over a white-collar worker; Letters opposing the St. Lawrence Seaway project; Brief of a case before the Supreme Court, concerning the forty-hour week and overtime wages.
B. Correspondence between Rixey Smith and the company which published the biography of Carter Glass by Smith and Norman Beaseley.

C. Correspondence with Henry Morgenthau, Secretary of the Treasury, including notes from the secretary thanking Carter Glass for supporting certain legislation, for example, continuation of the presidential power to devalue the dollar.

D. Correspondence concerning the attempt of William H. Peters to be reimbursed by the government for damages done to his family during the Civil War. Carter Glass expressed the opinion that introduction of such a bill would be fruitless.

A. Correspondence concerning persons eligible to fill vacant offices, particularly the position of Judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia : Letter of recommendation to Carter Glass; Carter Glass' recommendations.
A. Copies of reports submitted top the Board of Overseers of Sweet Briar College, of which Carter Glass was a member.

B. Correspondence concerning the possibility of constructing a large apartment house next to the Arlington Cemetery, rather than enlarging the cemetery, including a letter from President Franklin D. Roosevelt on the subject.
C. Correspondence relating to the Thomas Jefferson Bicentennial Commission, of which Carter Glass was Chairman; Letter from Howard Smith.
D. Items of correspondence concerning the possible repeal of the poll tax as a prerequisite, something which Carter Glass opposed.

E. Miscellaneous correspondence having to do largely with the recommending of people for jobs: Letters from Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, are included; Letter, February 25, 1941, expressing opposition to a change in reserve requirements designed to make it more difficult for the government to borrow from the Federal Reserve System; Small pamphlet concerning the excess profits tax.
F. Miscellaneous letters relating mostly to aid for England; Picture of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Glass.

A. Letters urging Carter Glass to support Wendell Wilkie to office; Protests against the booing of Carter Glass' references to Jefferson in a speech in Chicago; papers indicating great fear of New Deal and Franklin Delano Roosevelt; Great unrest in the country; Letters urging Carter Glass to put the country above party; Letters from across the country urging Carter Glass to put country above party.

A. Correspondence: Letters dealing with the proposed Longshoreman's and Harbor Worker's Compensation Act, mostly opposing the enactment of the legislation; Requests for support of the Murdock-Gillette Bill, S.1861; Suggestion, from Anchorage, Alaska, for the impeachment of the President, if he sent the Navy to the aid of the British; Other such suggestions; Letter stating opposition of the automobile dealers of Danville, Virginia, to a more strict Regulation; Other such letters; Numerous letters and telegrams suggesting legislation prohibiting the calling of strikes in industries vital to the defense program; Numerous letters asking for support for a measure affording a 15% pay raise for all postal employees; Letters expressing opposition to the St. Lawrence Seaway plan; a brief description of a possible Continental Defense Force, submitted by the American Legion at Norfolk; Numerous telegrams and letters pro and con over the Smith anti-strike bill, which Carter Glass favored; Pledges of support from various sources after December 7, 1941, for instance, an assurance of continuous war production from the National Association of Manufacturers; Letters and telegrams urge the adoption of price control legislation and rent controls; Letter enclosing an editorial from the Chicago Daily Tribune, December 4, 1941, stating that price controls were not yet needed, because of the limitations which would be placed on supply; Letter suggesting that Congress assert its authority over the President and enclosing two articles by Westbrook Pegler on the subject; Letter, December 4, 1941, from the representatives of the United Federal Workers of America, favoring price control while opposing wage-fixing; Telegram suggesting improvement in wording for the Lanham bill concerning defense housing, accompanied by a copy of the bill and a report by Lanham; Letters opposing the closed shop; Letter from the Gary, Indiana, Chamber of Commerce, favoring the St. Lawrence Seaway project; Form letter, November 28, 1941, from Woliam Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, opposing proposed anti-strike legislation; Suggestion to the Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau, that a tax on increases in income be levied, so that people not employed in defense industries would not be penalized.

A. Approximately 100 letters from all over the country, most of which were written in March, 1933, suggesting possible courses of action to meet the problems which caused the bank holiday, including guarantee of deposits and branch banking: Eight-page pamphlet by J. R. Edwards, "The Contamination of Credit"; Notes concerning the selling of preferred stock by banks to meet emergency needs sent to Carter Glass by Robert V. Fleming, President of Riggs National Bank; Twelve-page booklet, "Some ABC's of Currency Inflation," sent to Carter Glass by Edmund E. Lincoln, who had the advice of H. Parker Willis on the contents of the booklet; Letter from Walter Nesbit, a member of the House of Representatives, enclosing a letter from the Treasurer of the State of Illinois concerning the adverse effect on state funds of terminating the payment of interest on demand deposits; Digest of the Emergency Bank Bill of March, 1933, prepared by Charles W. Collins, sent to Carter Glass for his records by Gardner B. Perry, including lists of the emergency and permanent provisions of the bill.

A. Miscellaneous correspondence of a political nature; Several folders, including correspondence pertaining to appointment to Federal Judgeship in Western Virginia; Political and legislative correspondence with Harry F. Byrd; Folder concerning Governor Colgate W. Darden; Congressional pensions; Harry F. Byrd re-election; American Banker's Association and Joseph Leib.

A. Communication regarding the regulation of vice and liquor; Communication objecting to the passage of the Rivers and Harbors bill; Communication regarding the Longevity Bill; Communication regarding the regulation of installment sales; a bill proposing the sending of troops abroad; a communication against the limitations of the draft age; Communication favoring a manufacturers tax on gold as against a retail sales tax on jewelry; Communication urging that we stay out of the war; Communication regarding the admissions tax; Communication regarding the St. Lawrence Ship Canal; Letters regarding taxes and taxation; Letters that reject anti-strike legislation; Letters concerning the devaluation of the dollar; Letters requesting favors for workers on the Panama Canal; Miscellaneous communications, including such subject as daylight savings time, postal rates on books, limitation of automobile output, legislation to give the President power to seize property; Letters to Carter Glass regarding 19 different subjects, many not classified of classifiable; About 40 letters regarding vice and liquor conditions at Army camps and anti-strike legislation, devaluation of the dollar, foreign indebtedness and the national emergency, repeal of the Neutrality Act, opposition to increase of taxes on cigarettes and tobacco, request for increase of salaries of fourth class postmasters, requests for increases of federal pensions, price control and advertising rates or a tax on advertising, increase rates of pay for longshoremen, joint tax returns, consumer goods tax and tax on soft drinks; Letter from Ezra Taft Benson regarding farm price supports; Letter in opposition to Federal control of the oil industry, sugar quotas, convoys, radio broadcasting, Repeal of Neutrality Act, the power of the President to devalue the dollar, postal rates on books, proposed price ceiling on hardware, legislation for Panama Canal, daylight saving time; Letters to Carter Glass regarding some aspect of taxation, including retail installation sales; H.R.965 Burch salary and Longevity Bill; Letter of opposition to sending troops abroad; a letter opposed to drafting persons older than 28; Letter discussing the manufacturer's tax on jewelry; Letters opposed to the extension of the draft bill; Letter urging that we stay out of the war; Letter opposing tax on admissions to Agricultural Fairs; Opposition to a tax on wire and equipment service; Letter against tax on bank checks; Letter regarding houses for District of Columbia workers; Letter regarding tax on furs, tobacco and gas; Letters complaining of a discriminatory tax on lumber manufacturers; Letter regarding the taxation of outdoor advertising; S.R.124 a bill proposing that we feed the small children of Europe; a letter proposing the exemption of gold mines from excess profits; Letter regarding the exemption of charity organizations from a tax; Letters regarding the tax on admissions, St. Lawrence Ship Canal, tax on unmarried men, letters regarding sales tax; Letters regarding the Property Seizure Act, Old Age Pensions, excess profits and others; Letter regarding the regulation of the size and weight of trucks, the removal of patent office; Letter regarding state erected trade barriers; Letter from E. D. Jeffries, 13 May 1941, regarding installment credit; Several letters in favor of 48 hour week; Letters from McKellar regarding the Tennessee Valley Authority program.

A. Miscellaneous correspondence: St. Lawrence Seaway, Senate Bill 860 relating to prohibition of intoxicating beverages near military camps, opposition to the Jones Amendment to H. R. 4276, daylight savings time, taxes, postmasters pay, hours for opening of barber shops, etc.

A. Letters, telegrams, petitions, etc. concerning current legislative matters: Letters regarding numerous miscellaneous tax levies; Letters opposing the entry of the United States in war, especially as an ally of the Russians; Numerous letters concerning the method of payment and longevity pay for fourth-class postmasters; Letter, July 30, 1941, from the vice president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, complaining of the burdens imposed on the steel industry by a new method of computing excess profits taxes and additional taxes on invested capital; Letter, July 29, 1941, from a small steel fabricator attempting to show the adverse effect on working capital of the proposed tax on invested capital; Communication from the Interstate Commerce Committee of the Senate enclosing a bill to equalize freight rates between different geographical areas for defense materials; Requests that Carter Glass vote against extension of the draft for one year, July, 1941; Letter from a Tennessee voter severely reprimanding Carter Glass for giving in to the New Deal philosophy by voting for the extension of the devaluation power; Letter from the vice president of the Sabune Royalty Corporation of Texas, suggesting a fair rate of return on investment be insured by spreading a heavy tax burden over a longer period of time; Form letter from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, opposing the power granted the President to take over certain defense plants in the event of failure to comply with regulations; Telegrams protesting an order of July, 1941, that automobile production be reduced; Several Letters expressing the hope that the Neutrality Act would be repealed; Eight-page statement addressed to the Office of Price Administration Administrator by the president of the National Cotton Council, opposing the fixing of a price ceiling on cottonseed oil, suggesting alternative plan to a ceiling.

did.unittitle: Correspondence relating to the Fight for Freedom Committee 1941

scopecontent.p: A. Letters, Pamphlets, etc. sent to Carter Glass in his capacity as honorary Chairman of the Fight for Freedom Committee : Sixteen page booklet entitled "What Is the Fight for Freedom?"; Letter from Carter Glass, September 15, 1941, stating that he approves immediate entry of the United States into the war against Hitler; Numerous statements and progress reports by the organization; Excerpts from a speech, June 30, 1941, by James B. Conant, regarding the entry of the United States into the actual and ideological struggle against Hitler; Copy of an address given by the Assistant Secretary of War, June 14, 1941, concerning the military capacity of the United States; Statements opposing the Hoover plan to break a British blockade in order to get food to France, which was economically but not yet actually under Nazi control; Letters expressing sentiment favorable toward entering active combat along with the British against the Nazis; Copy of a speech, May 19, 1941, by Francis Pickens Miller, urging the entry of the United States into the war with Germany; Letters in varying views, some urging declaration of war, some suggesting a declaration of national emergency, others begging that the country be kept out of war. Moat letters favor active participation in the war; Letters criticizing Congress for its failure to act in getting aid for Britain; Address, May 4, 1941, by James B. Conant just after his return from England, urging the United States to enter the war immediately; Telegrams requesting that Carter Glass accept the honorary chairmanship of the Fight for Freedom Committee.

A. Several letters expressing opposition to regulation of freight forwarding companies by the Interstate Commerce Commission, suggested by Senator Truman, among others; Letter favoring lend lease bill to aid England in defending against the Nazis; Letters complaining of the expected adverse results of certain amendments to the Fair Labor Standard Act on canneries; Letter from a New Jersey banker, protesting the giving of greater power to the Comptroller of the Currency; Letter, January 18, 1941, enclosing three resolutions passed by the Congress of Industrial Organization (CIO); Several letters favoring the St. Lawrence Seaway project; ten page pamphlet suggesting revaluation of the dollar in terms solely of gold and opposing use of alloys in the coin, while troy measure if depended upon; Suggestions for changing existing monetary laws; In answer to the question, "Should the power of the Federal Government be increased?" Carter Glass says, "the power of the federal government has been already increased too much"; Letters requesting legislation designed to prevent strikes in times of emergency; Forty-one page "Report of the Chief of the Forest Service," 1940; Small twelve-page pamphlet prepared by the United States Chamber of Commerce suggesting amendments to the Excess Profits Tax Act; Fifteen page pamphlet from the Federal Power Commission, "Scheduled Additions to Generating Capacity and Electric Construction Expenditures"; Twenty-seven page report by the Federal Loan Agency listing its defense commitments; a large number of form letters asking that Carter Glass oppose the sale of intoxicating liquors at military camps; Report, May 8, 1941, relating to the condition of the merchant marine.

A. Letters on miscellaneous topics which were concerning legislators at the time: Booklet, "Typical Electric Bills," prepared in 1941 by the Federal Power Commission; Numerous letters express opposition to the St. Lawrence Seaway proposal; Letters opposing the granting of a monopoly to lawyers appearing before governmental agencies in litigation cases; Letters opposing the lowering of qualifications for mine inspector; Letters opposing the sale of alcoholic beverages at military installations; Letter from the Commissioner of Agriculture on July 23, 1941, requesting that Congress change the base period for calculation of parity prices from 1910-1914 to 1920-1929; Letter written in July, 1941, in opposition to a one year extension of the time in service of a draftee; Several letters regarding the repeal of fair trade contracts in interstate commerce (Miller-Tydings amendment); Letter, April 15, 1941, from James J. Davis, a member of the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs, requesting the holding of hearings by Carter Glass' committee on the extent of monopoly enjoyed by the German Dye Trust; Telegrams requesting Carter Glass to work in behalf of southern coal operators and in opposition to requirements backed by northern operators and the United Mine Workers.

A. Letter, September 17, 1942, from the New York State Economic Council, expressing opposition to the taxing of state and municipal bonds by the federal government, other similar letters; Brief letter proposing severe limitations upon the Federal Reserve Board, and radical changes in the act, from Thomas E. Pugh; President of the Merchants and Manufacturers Association sends a list of reasons for favoring a sales tax over the taxing of income; Telegrams received on September 22, 1942, urged Carter Glass to vote for the inclusion of the cost of labor in setting farm prices and for support at 90% of parity instead of 85%; Letters concerning problems with respect to renegotiation; Several letters from Walter F. George, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance, acknowledging receipt of the letters of several Virginia ns, concerning tax legislation, from Carter Glass; Several letters relate to he effect of the excess profits tax; Letter from Tom Connally, chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, noting enclosure of an amended copy of a bill under consideration; Letter from a small businessman complaining of the undue exercise of power by the National War Labor Board. Enclosed is a statement from the president of Inland Steel showing the unjust action of the Board with respect to the closed shop requirement; Seven-page report, concerning the 1942 tax bill then under consideration, prepared by a committee for the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce; Six letter, referred to Leon Henderson, Office of Price Administration Administrator, and returned to Carter Glass, concerning small gas rationing for salesmen.

A. Letters and telegrams on many subjects such as rationing, price and wage controls, etc.: Letter from a Virginia contractor, addressed to the Office of Price Administration stating why it is practically impossible to set an upper limit on the price of a job; Pamphlet favoring a pay-as-you-go plan for income taxes during the war and opposing paying taxes on the income of the previous year; Resolution suggesting that income from municipal securities remain tax-free; Telegram, December 8, 1942, from the president of the National Association of Building Owners and Manufacturers, asking delay in action on a rent control bill which is objectionable as it stands; Letter, July 14, 1942, from Leon Henderson, Office of Price Administration Administrator, dispelling rumors regarding anticipated action with respect to tobacco growers; Letter from Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, with objections to proposed use of increased appropriations for defense purposes.

A. Letters regarding change in the draft age; Letters urging regulation of the sale of liquor to service men; Wage raise for postal service men; Support for the anti-poll tax bill; Silver bill to Senator Green; Anti-inflation bill has many supporting letters; Letters urging support of farm prices; Letters urging formation of Pharmacy Corps in the Army; Letters of protest against Petrillo; Letters vs. the proposed tax on securities; Taxation of mutual insurance companies -letters for and against.
B. Letters from persons who are interested in defeating or passing legislation referred to above.

A. Letters on pending or proposed legislation, pro and con, from people in many states including: Letters from postal members; labor union officials; letters regarding the sale of liquor near Army posts to servicemen; letters regarding a 48 hour week.
B. Letter referring to the Federal Reserve System, relating to the regulation of installment credit.

A. Letters on a wide variety of subjects all of which were under consideration at the time Letter, June 13, 1942, from Robert F. Wagner to Carter Glass, enclosing a brief report by D. W. Bell, Acting Secretary of the Treasury. The letter states Treasury Department approval of three proposed amendments to the Federal Reserve Act. The proposals include: changing of the method of election for members of the Open Market Committee, change in reserve requirements for member banks in central reserve cities, and lessening the severity of provisions relating to treatment of banks having deficiencies in reserves; Memorandum, June 11, 1942, from Senator Walter George, concerning reference to him of letters about a proposed sales tax by Carter Glass; Letter, April 22, 1942, from Robert F. Wagner, enclosing a report from the Treasury Department encouraging the purchase of defense bonds to control inflation; Booklet sent to Carter Glass proposing that a tax on value added during wartime would be the best way to finance the war; Letter, April 1, 1942, from Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, concerning reduced appropriation for tobacco insect investigations.

A. Letters requesting the support of Carter Glass for certain pending legislation of his opposition to certain measures, covering a wide range of topics that were under discussion during this period: On June 28, 1941, Donald Wheeler, assistant clerk of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee sending a copy of the bill "to authorize national banks to pledge assets to secure deposits of funds in official custody of public officers of a state."

A. Letters concerning the bill to establish an Inter-American Bank, correspondence for the most part expressing opposition to the continuation after 1941 of the power of the President to devalue the dollar; Letters from Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, concerning bills before the committee, numerous letters accompanied by copies of bills being considered by the Committee; Letters to and from Robert F. Wagner, and miscellaneous letters on banking and currency; Letter from Henry Morgenthau, Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.

B. Inter-American Bank bill: Correspondence with Marriner Eccles concerning amendments to the bill creating the Inter-American Bank; Copy of amendment to the bill suggested by several Senators, including Carter Glass and Alben Barkley, whose signatures are affixed; Copy of the hearings before the Senate subcommittee of the Committee on Foreign Relations, May 5-6, 1941; Copy of a message from the President to the Senate concerning the Inter-American Bank bill; Eight-page paper prepared by W. Randolph Burgess at the request of Carter Glass on the advisability of establishing an Inter-American Bank; Similar opinion prepared upon request by George L. Harrison; Letter, April 24, 1942, from Sumner Wells, Under Secretary of State, rendering opinions on proposed amendments to the Inter-American Bank bill; History of the Inter-American Bank Corporation from a legislative standpoint, prepared by Sumner Wells for President Franklin D. Roosevelt on March 25, 1942; Letter, May 22, 1941, from Leo T. Crowley, Chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation analyzing the results of the Inter-American Bank Convention.

C. Continuation of presidential power to devalue the dollar after 1941: Letter from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Henry A. Wallace, president of the United States Senate, asking that his power to devalue the currency remain in effect; Numerous letters expressing favor for the lapse of the power to devalue the dollar; One of the many letters opposing the continuation of the President's power to devalue the currency was written on May 26, 1941, from G. D. Mathews to Senator Harry S. Truman.

D. Fourteen letters to Carter Glass from Robert F. Wagner, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, most of which are accompanied by enclosures, which include reports from D. W. Bell, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and a report written by E. A. Goldenweiser submitted by Marriner Eccles. The reports deal with such things as the establishment of branches by government chartered financial institutions, the insurance of bank deposits, stabilizing the value of the dollar, Federal credit unions, and retirement of Federal Reserve bank notes.

E. Correspondence between Carter Glass and Robert F. Wagner, 1938-1946: Several letter relating to Palestine and the Jews; References to the work of the Office of Price Administration; Pamphlet on Bretton Woods; Letter from Carter Glass expressing opposition to the Maybank bill of 1944, permitting the payment of interest on demand deposits through the absorption of exchange and collection charges and favoring par clearance; Personal letter in handwriting from Robert F. Wagner to Carter Glass; Eight-page pamphlet prepared for Robert F. Wagner by Chester Morrill, secretary of the Board of Governors, stating the reasons for opposing the payment of interest on demand deposits; a copy of the hearings and a copy of the bill on the absorption of exchange; Copy of the committee report on the proposed trust Indenture Act, May, 1938, along with a letter from George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, expressing opposition to this type of corporate financing; Telegram, May 7, 1938, from Carter Glass to Elihu Root; Letter from Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, favoring the liquidation of loans by member banks to their officers; a report from Roswell Magill, Acting Secretary of the Treasury in March, 1938, recommending that taxes not be required of trust companies in full or partial liquidation; Report, March 30, 1938, from Wayne C. Taylor, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, suggesting that the lending powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation be increased.

F. Miscellaneous Correspondence, 9 items: Letter, May 12, 1941, to Robert F. Wagner from Henry Morgenthau, Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, on increasing the lending power of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation; Telegram from B. M. Anderson requesting a one month postponement of hearings on a bill concerning investment trusts.

G. Miscellaneous correspondence: Letter, 2 June 1942, from D. W. Bell sent to Carter Glass by Senator Robert F. Wagner, regarding amendments to P.S.5136 authorizing national banks to reimburse officers for any expense incurred in the discharge of duties or lawsuit; Copy of a bill amending the Federal Reserve Act, regarding the election of representatives of Reserve banks on the open market committee; Amendment to the Federal Reserve Act, giving the Board power to alter Reserve requirements; Letter from Senator Robert F. Wagner, 11 June, 1941, with letter from Crowley to Robert F. Wagner, regarding the effect of S.2393; Letter from Secretary Bell to Robert F. Wagner regarding S.2393; Copy of a bill requiring an insured bank to publish in its statement of resources and liabilities certain facts; Letter, 6 December 1941, Leo T. Crowley to Robert F. Wagner regarding indemnification of directors for expenses incurred in defending actions on behalf of their bank; S.3029 on the same subject; S.3126, a bill authorizing the issuance of defense stamps, sent to Carter Glass by the clerk of the Committee on Banking and Currency; S.1905, a bill requiring Reserve Banks to pay interest on reserve balances of member banks. July 15 letter of Crowley to Robert F. Wagner sent to Carter Glass of the Senate Committee, with the opinion of Crowley regarding extension of bank facilities on military reservations; a bill, 19 May 1941, terminating all power of President to further devalue the dollar by June 30, 1943; Letter, Leo T. Crowley to Robert F. Wagner regarding the need of a stabilization fund; H.R.4646, an Act to limit the time in which powers relative to the stabilization fund may be exercised; S.1471, 7 May 1941, a memorandum regarding the power to pledge government securities for collateral for Federal Reserve notes issued to Reserve Banks; Letter from Chester Morrill regarding S.1471; Copy of S.1471 providing an extension and the right to pledge government securities; Letter from Chester Morrill to Robert F. Wagner regarding the passage of S.1471; Letter from Labor Department regarding S.1098 of bill to outlaw branch banking companies, 12 March 1941; Letter of J. Michaelson to Carter Glass urging passage of bill to outlaw branch banking companies, 12 March 1941; Letter of W. R. White, Superintendent of New York Banks, 17 March 1941. 1941 review of state banking; Letter, 2 June 1942, Secretary of the Treasury Bell to Senator Carter Glass regarding bill to authorize National Banks to reimburse directors for expenses incurred by them in suits and actions invoking their positions and functions; Letter William W. White to Carter Glass giving views of New York State Banking Board on Senate #310 and specific proposed amendments to the Federal Reserve Act, 17 March 1941; Letter of E. C. Romph regarding Senate Bill #310 and asking that it be amended so that it would be applicable to banks doing business in a state which does not permit branch banking; Bill amending Federal Reserve Act, section 12B, regarding waiver by Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation under certain circumstances stated therein. Comments by Secretary Bell, 26 March 1941; Leo T. Crowley to Robert F. Wagner, 14 March 1941, regarding S.952 and especially to section 4 therein that every insured bank must comply with the reserve requirements of the Federal Reserve System. Crowley objects to the enforcement of this provision as it relates to state banks; S.1098 referred to Carter Glass which would require the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve Banks and the treasury to restore and maintain the average purchasing power of the dollar as determined by the Department of Labor, 14 March 1941; Letter of 24 January 1941, to Robert F. Wagner from Bethea regarding 5390, a bill relative to foreign accounts in Reserve banks and in insured banks; "Who Owns the Federal Reserve Banks," a letter to Carter Glass, 9 February 1941. Answer of Carter Glass not attaches; Letter to John Wyeth and others regarding the resolution enabling American national to pay funds due abroad into a revolving fund, that such nationals are not allowed to pay funds due to individuals in this country; Memorandum of Dorsey Cole and Garner regarding SJ3 in its application to Norway, 14 February 1941.

A. Approximately 50-75 letters praising a statement made by Carter Glass in 1943 in which he appealed to the people to adjourn politics and proceed with winning the war; Ca. 35 letters addressed to Carter Glass requesting him to vote either for or against ratification of the United Nations Charter, 1945; Probably upwards of 250 letters requesting Carter Glass' support of a bill which proposes to increase salaries of postal employees and acknowledgments by Carter Glass' secretary, 1945; Ca. 10 letters from the editor of a Princeton University -sponsored society to publish the works of Thomas Jefferson; Annual report of the editor and several reprints of papers, 1945; Correspondence, 1914, urging Carter Glass to vote either for or against legislation making it possible for all members of the armed forces to exercise voting privileges by some sort of uniform ballot; Ca. 35 letters of a slightly later date commending his vote; Several letters and newspaper clippings referring to the 86th birthday of Carter Glass, 1944.

A. Birthday greetings, 1944, from numerous persons, including Senators, the Comptroller of the Currency, J. Edgar Hoover, members of the Cabinet, and friends like John Stewart Bryan and Francis P. Gaines.
B. Birthday Greetings, 1945, from numerous friends, including Congressmen, Henry Morgenthau, James F. Byrnes, William Tuck, and Bernard M. Baruch, among others.
C. Birthday greetings, 1946, from many friends, including Senators Harry F. Byrd and Robert F. Wagner and Colgate W. Darden, Governor of Virginia.

did.unittitle:
Correspondence concerning Office of Price Administration legislation
1944-1946

scopecontent.p: A. Letters concerning easing of rent controls, suggesting the lightening of certain restrictions imposed by the Office of Price Administration, and Carter Glass' correspondence on matters directly relating to the Office of Price Administration.

B. Rent Control: Letters advocating support of a 15% increase in rents, as suggested by a House amendment, or complete abolition of controls; Proposal by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York that rent controls be discontinued when state laws afford adequate protection.

C. Letters, telegrams, etc. criticizing Office of Price Administration policies and suggesting enactment of legislation more sympathetic to the needs of business: Letters objecting to the request by Chester Bowles that people strongly oppose a Congressman who voted to restrict Office of Price Administration operations, abolition of Office of Price Administration is said to be preferable, the agency should at least be overhauled; Letters stating that Office of Price Administration policies are such as to force liquidation or at best encourage black markets; Letters favoring House amendments in 1936 to the Price Control Bill; Opposition expressed to the Cost absorption policy of the Office of Price Administration. It is desired that prices be set on the basis of costs plus the historical mark-up; Numerous letters suggesting that Office of Price Administration be discontinued completely in favor of a free economy, despite cries of inflation, etc. by the defenders of the Office of Price Administration. Many personal experiences are cited to illustrate the inapplicability of Office of Price Administration policies; Numerous letters from lumber concerns; Letters suggesting that the Office of Price Administration give up trying to regulate prices of meat and cattle.

D. Correspondence containing a wide variety of questions regarding Office of Price Administration policies: Letters from Chester Bowles, Paul Porter and Prentiss Brown, concerning actions taken by the Office of Price Administration on a wide variety of matters; Fourteen-page pamphlet prepared by the Office of Price Administration stating objections to amendments to the Price Control Act, proposed in 1942; Report, June 27, 1944, by Chester Bowles, stating that the Office of Price Administration would not be adversely affected by the proposed Stabilization Extension Bill; Letter, September 14, 1943, from Chester Bowles to Carter Glass, stating that rationing, price control, and rent control are difficult subjects, upon which he and Carter Glass do not always agree. a progress report on the Office of Price Administration is included.

did.unittitle: Correspondence on the extension of Office of Price Administration 1946

scopecontent.p: A. Letters, postcard, telegrams, etc. urging the continuation of the functions of the Office of Price Administration for one year after its date of expiration in 1946, so as to prevent inflation: Particular opposition is expressed to the Map revision of the Office of Price Administration law, regulating pricing methods; Several letters favor continuation of price control only if more equitable methods are adopted and if a fair profit can be allowed. Several letters suggest changes in the Office of Price Administration law; Several letters cite restriction of production, black market development, and hoarding in opposing the continuation of Office of Price Administration; Many telegrams were sent to Carter Glass by unions urging continuation of Office of Price Administration; Several letters concerning the possibility of greater leniency with respect to rent control; a letter from a coffee importing organization urges an end to all price controls and importation controls; Some few letters record opposition to Office of Price Administration and suggest that, until production can be increased until production can be increased until it approximately matches demand, some type of plan should be instituted, whereby profits could be restricted, rather than prices. The suggestion is made that controls be dropped on those items for which the supply is adequate to meet the demand; The Castle Realty Corporation lists the four amendments to the Office of Price Administration law, which so many people found so objectionable, and gives reasons for favoring the action of the House in accepting these amendments; Fourteen one-page statements concerning price control, collected by unbiased persons at the Library of Congress and published at the Public Affairs Abstracts, including statements by Chester Bowles, Bernard M. Baruch, Marriner Eccles, John W. Snyder, Fred M. Vinson, and Seymour E. Harris, among others.

A. Papers regarding repeal of 18th amendment; Letters to people seeking tickets to change convention; 1929 letters to party workers; Letters regarding party patronage and relief; Letters from and to Carter Glass regarding Senate campaign; Folder of letters regarding election, party conventions, etc.; Letters and attachments regarding party platforms and conventions; Letters and papers regarding party matters; Correspondence with Jim Farley.

A. Clippings descriptions relating to Bishop James Cannon, the Federal Reserve Board, court packing bill, and miscellaneous matters: Elihu Root's speech regarding the Woodrow Wilson administration in the New York Evening Post, May 16, 1916; Carter Glass' response to Elihu Root's attack on currency bill, New York Evening Journal, 17 December 1913; Editorial in Portsmouth Star, 26 December 1934, regarding Carter Glass' attack on the Franklin D. Roosevelt administration; Marriner Eccles accepts Carter Glass bill as amended regarding open market committee; Fifteen or more clippings, mostly editorials, from many papers regarding Carter Glass' attack on the court packing bill, etc.; Clippings regarding brain trusts, 1 April 1939; Some good editorials regarding court packing bill, 1 April 1939; Editorial in New York Evening Postregarding Elihu Root's speech against the administration; Carter Glass responds to Elihu Root charges against the currency reform bill ( Richmond Virginian, 17 December 1913); Carter Glass scored Elihu Root and Vanderlip; Editorial in the Times Dispatchon Carter Glass' speech, 17 December 1913; New York Evening World, 10 September 1913, on Carter Glass' defense of currency bill in the House; Article from San Antonio Express, 21 December 1913, on Congressman Henry's defense of the currency bill. He agreed with the President on the bill, but not with Carter Glass; "The interpreter" in the St. Paul Pioneer Press, 7 January 1936, holds that the Democrats revamped the Aldrich Bill; Editorial in the Fargo Forumon the Carter Glass speech on Court Packing Bill, 2 April 1937; Carter Glass' speech on the Court Packing Bill in Chicago Tribune, 30 March 1937; Editorial from Lincoln State Journalon the Carter Glass speech on court packing bill, 3 April 1937; Frederick A. Delano on Debt Funding operations; Fredericksburg Democrat, 4 September 1913, on the President's commendations of Carter Glass on the management of the Currency Bill in the House; "Currency Bill is helped by Bryan," Roanoke paper, 24 August 1918; The Financial Age, New York, 3 June 1918, on foreign branches for banks; Clipping on Carter Glass' address at Ashland on Patrick Henry; New York Daily News, an article on tax exempt securities and on inflation by Ralph Robey; An editorial, "Just Carter Glass " regarding Carter Glass' attitude toward Morgan; Editorial in Times Dispatch, 23 January 1933, " Carter Glass for Treasury Post"; Editorial in Lexington Herald, 2 January 1933, " Carter Glass for Treasury Post"; Article in Toledo Blade, March 3, 1939, on the Court Packing proposal; The court packing proposal in the Mitchell, S. D. Gazette, no date; Carter Glass versus Robinson on the Court Packing plan in St. Louis Globe, 1 April 1939; Carter Glass versus Robinson on Court Packing plan in Newport News Daily Press, 31 March 1937; The Knickerbocker Press, 31 March 1937, on Carter Glass' famous address; Editorial in the Pittsburgh Press, 30 March 1937, on Carter Glass' career; Tulsa Worldregarding court packing, no date; Congressman Henry on the Currency Bill in Waco News, 17 June 1914; Roanoke Times, 17 January 1914, on Carter Glass and Henry; Houston Post, 14 January 1914, on Carter Glass and Henry; Philadelphia Public Ledger, 26 June 1913, on Secretary Carter Glass and the currency bill; Editorial " Carter Glass " in Roanoke World News, no date; Editorial on Carter Glass and Henry, 26 July 1936; Editorial on Hughes and Carter Glass, no source and no date; Many clippings regarding Democratic party in Virginia, Carter Glass and Court Packing Bill, Currency legislation and Carter Glass, miscellaneous activities of Carter Glass, others on Carter Glass in some respect; Numerous unmounted clippings.

B. Miscellaneous clippings: Number 22 of a series of A. D. H. Smith in the New York Evening Post, May 2, 1918, on Colonel House, and others; Clippings relating to Bishop James Cannon; Editorials and articles relating to the position of Carter Glass with respect to the Glass-Steagall Act; Miscellaneous clippings, January 11, 1914 -December 25, 1914; Clippings relating to Bishop James Cannon and the prohibition movement, many sources, 1936, 1937; Clippings on federal reserve bill, court packing bill, and miscellaneous subjects; 27 items regarding Carter Glass' stand on the court packing bill; Acceptance by Marriner Eccles of the Carter Glass bill as amended with respect to open market operations; Clippings regarding the court packing bill; Editorial on the "Brain Trust."

A. General clippings having to do largely with the Federal Reserve System : Editorials and articles written during December, 1913, concerning the Federal Reserve Act: acceptance of the report of the conference committee by the Senate, and signing of the bill by President Woodrow Wilson, and an editorial discussion of the measure, its legislative history and its anticipated performance; New York Herald Tribune, February 8, 1935, editorial condemning President Franklin D. Roosevelt for seeking excessive power; Articles and editorials concerning monetary legislation in the 1930's, including criticisms; New York Herald, December 23, 1913, widespread opinion cited that John Skelton Williams would be made Comptroller of the Currency; Letter to Washington Heraldwritten on October 27, 1933, from Hearst, criticizing the National Recovery Administration; New York Times, March 13, 1933, describing an argument between Senators Carter Glass and Huey Long, Louisiana Democrat over admission of state banks to the Federal Reserve System; Letter of October 17, 1931, from Carter Glass to the New York Timeseditor, dealing with the Goldhurst-Cannon case; Editorials and articles written during April and May, 1935, criticizing the proposed banking legislation of hat year largely on the grounds of increased control over credit by political interests; Washington Herald, May 13, 1935, the Hearst chain records opposition to the proposed banking bill, citing the criticisms by Frank A. Vanderlip of the plan offered by Marriner Eccles; Newspaper clipping in which H. Parker Willis criticizes the banking legislation proposed by Marriner Eccles; Norfolk Ledger-Dispatch, suggestion that Carter Glass will look thoroughly into the case before allowing Marriner Eccles to be appointed chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; Newspaper article in which Samuel Untermeyer praises the part of the Carter Glass bill refusing permission for banks to be associated directly with security companies; New York Times, February 12, 1932, editorial explaining the reserve and rediscount features of the proposed amendments to the Federal Reserve Act; Columbus Evening Dispatch, May 27, 1933, editorial credits Senator Carter Glass with the preparation of provisions of the Glass-Steagall Act whereby deposits are guaranteed; Editorials and articles concerning Carter Glass' defense of J. P. Morgan in 1933, when the conduct of a Congressional investigation of the financial affairs of the family struck Carter Glass as being unfair; Caption for a picture of Carter Glass and Senator David A. Reed (Republican from Pennsylvania ) in 1933 states that Carter Glass will argue in favor of a downward revision of war debts; Newspaper articles, May, 1933, describing certain of the compromises which Congress men Carter Glass and Steagall were making an effort to present a bill meeting administrative approval; New Orleans states, May 8, 1933, editorial giving figures on the bonded debt of Louisiana with intent to prove tendency toward bankruptcy under Huey Long; Hammond Vindicator, March 17, 1933, lengthy article criticizing the financial policies of the Huey Long administration; St. Louis Post Dispatch, March 10, 1933, Senator Carter Glass brings to light an opinion delivered in 1911 by Frederick W. Lehmann, Solicitor General, stating that any connection between commercial banks and investment companies was illegal; Articles defending Carter Glass' position in choosing to remain in the Senate, rather than become Secretary of the Treasury under President Franklin D. Roosevelt; New York Times, March 9, 1933, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of Chase National Bank, stating that the connection between the bank and the Chase Securities Corporation will be broken and suggesting further reforms in addition to those of the Carter Glass bill; Roanoke World News, May 19, 1930, editorial praising Carter Glass states that " Oscar Underwood, of Alabama, would not stand for re-election in a state that could elect Heflin"; Letter from Carter Glass to John Stewart Bryan, editor of the Richmond News Lead, stating that the United States made a mistake in refusing to enter the League of Nations; Envelope of clippings concerning various subjects, particularly brief articles either favorable of unfavorable to the work of Carter Glass in the financial sphere during the 1930's, also clippings about Bishop James Cannon, including a report of the opposition to the Carter Glass bill by the New York Chamber of Commerce; several articles relating to the proper extension of credit by the Federal Reserve System and the use of such credit for speculative purposes, including an article by H. Parker Willis in the Washington Evening Star, January 24, 1929, suggesting the contraction of credit through suspension of many brokers' loans and the withdrawal of credit extended for speculative purposes; Wall Street Journal, February 5, 1929, suggestion by Carter Glass noted favorably that reserve requirements on time deposits be raised to lessen the volume of brokers' loans being extended; Editorial reprinting a statement of H. Parker Willis that the banking bill of 1935 is not in line with the original concepts and allocates too much control over the system to political interests. The 1935 bill is said by the editor to represent the logical conclusion to the act of January 30, 1934, whereby the Federal Reserve Board controls the system and the board is subservient to the Treasury. The board under Marriner Eccles is said to consist solely of democrats; Article citing opposition of Benjamin M. Anderson to setting reserve requirements according to the velocity of bank deposits. Anderson states that a reserve requirement should be set according to liquidity of other assets, irregularity of net demand liabilities, and variability in customers borrowing demands; Letter to the editor of the New York Timeswritten February 3, 1932, stating that the Carter Glass bill shows a lack of knowledge money market phenomena in those sections discouraging use of Federal Reserve credit for speculative purposes; Article in the New York Herald Tribunecontaining an interview with Marriner Eccles just after he became Secretary of the Board; Philadelphia Record, on the day before the Carter Glass subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee reported the Carter Glass bill, expressed the opinion that the Marriner Eccles suggestions should be restored, after having been replaced by the Carter Glass committee at the instance of certain Wall Street interests; Baltimore Sun, May 27, 1935, editor attacks Marriner Eccles for favoring political domination of the banking system; St. Louis Globe Democrat, May 16, 1935, editorial says the United States is not on the gold standard and that the dollar is unsound; Article noting that Marriner Eccles, Chairman of the Board of Governors and ardent New Dealer, had employed a public relations man; Washington Herald, May 31, 1935, President Franklin D. Roosevelt is pictured as an advocate of the Marriner Eccles plan for the banking system; Washington Herald, May 31, 1935, article states that President Franklin D. Roosevelt was willing to surrender certain of the powers to be granted the administration under the Marriner Eccles banking bill in view of the opposition of the American Bankers Association; Envelope of miscellaneous clippings dealing largely with the activity of Bishop James Cannon in the election of 1928, especially the means by which his campaign against Alfred E. Smith was financed; Articles dealing with stock market activity in 1929 and the early 1930's; Several articles dealing with changes in eligibility requirements in 1935; New York Journal of Commerce, December, 195, proposal by McAdoo and John Skelton Williams of the Treasury Department that the Federal Advisory Council be abolished, despite the relative inactivity of the group; The North American, November 30, 1915, Carter Glass prepares to attack the Federal Advisory Council, mentioning James B. Forgan, J. P. Morgan, George M. Reynolds, and Robert L. Owen; Editorial stating that there was still time to correct the defects of the 1935 banking bill, the defects are enumerated; Communication relating to brokers' loans and the Federal Reserve System; a page from a bulletin of Nelson, Cook & Co. regarding brokers loans and control of credit; Tom Heflin Resolution asking the Board of Governors to suggest legislation designed to control speculation; a clipping from the New York Herald Tribune, 25 March 1820, regarding the definition of speculation by Carter Glass and the editor; Limitations on collateral loans proposed by M. H. Cahill in New York Times, 12 November 1929; Letter to Herald Tribuneby William A. Sumner relative to the formation of the Liberal Party and a letter by Sumner to Carter Glass, 23 May 1935; Letter of Franklin of Louisville regarding the centralization of power, cf. to Carter Glass, 15 July 1935; "Sturdy Old Roman" -Editorial, Boston Herald, 26 February 1935, regarding standard of Carter Glass on Federal Aid; Richmond Palladium, 10 December 1929; Article by R. G. Leeds on benefits of stock market crash; Glass-Steagall Act described in Business Week, 20 February 1932; Article by T. B. MacCauly (a distinguished Canadian), "a Weakness of our Credit Structure"; New York Times, 28 February 1934 -statement regarding margin requirements, refers to Thomas G. Corcoran and the drafting of Stock Control Bill; Attack on New Deal by John W. Davis, New York Times, 28 February 1934. Letter to Carter Glass from Davis; Elliott Thurston, Washington Post, 16 May 1934, regarding Carter Glass and the Stock Exchange Bill; Address of Fred C. Clark in the American Banker, 13 June ?; Portrait of a Senator, no date, no source, tribute to Carter Glass; Editorial in the New York Timeson the revised Federal Reserve bill, discussing changes and controversies; New York Herald Tribune, July 4, 1935, an article on the curbs on New Deal laws by the Supreme Court; Article in the Philadelphia Inquiryabout speech of ? Sir Josiah Stamp on the return to the gold standard; Editorial in the Washington Post, 11 May 1935, speaking favorably of changes for he better in the Federal Reserve Act; Address of Ogden Mills at the Harvard Club analyzing the Federal Reserve Act and the Steagall Bill, and some of its dangers, no source and not date; Article discussing the origin of the power of Reserve Banks to make international loans; Editorial in Richmond Times Dispatch, 18 May 1934, regarding Carter Glass amendments to Fletcher-Rayburn Bill; Mention in the Washington Post, 16 May 1934, by Elliott Thurston, It tells of Carter Glass' resignation from the Conference Committee on the Securities Bill; Editorial in the Petersburg Progress-Index, no date, on the failure of Harry F. Byrd and Carter Glass to vote for the bill regulating utilities.

A. Political campaigns of 1920, 1924, and 1936: Democratic Presidential Nominating Convention of 1924. It was in this year that Carter Glass was a strong contender for the nomination. Editorials, mostly from state papers, are prolific. Carter Glass' stand on the New Deal is covered in the 1936 Presidential election.

B. Activities of Bishop James Cannon of the Methodist church; articles on the Federal Reserve System and various banking legislation. Of special note on the latter subject if coverage of a controversy between Carter Glass and Colonel House over responsibility for getting the Federal Act written; Controversy between Carter Glass and Senator Tom Heflin over he merits and shortcomings of the system.
C. Activities and alleged "wrong doings" of the Virginia State veterinarian, Dr. J. G. Ferneyhough and reported "meddling" in the retirement of Major General Cronkhite.

D. Editorials on Banking and Currency legislation, including nominations of Charles S. Hamlin to Federal Reserve Board, New Bedford, Massachusetts Morning Mercury, July 3, 1926, and Carter Glass' warning against the liberalizing of regulations governing eligible paper for borrowing at the Federal Reserve banks, undated; Approximately 10 editorials, undated, referring to the announcement of J. Cloyd Byans to run as an "Independent Democrat" against Carter Glass for Congress; Editorials and articles, date 1926, dealing with failure to re-elect Dr. J. G. Ferneyhough as state veterinarian and some controversy between Fenneyhough and Carter Glass; Articles giving Carter Glass' views regarding proposed McFadden National Bank Bill and Hull amendments, (dated ?); Reports of speech by Carter Glass against proposed Hange-McNary Farm Bill, 1926; Reports of activities of Bishop James Cannon, undated. Also editorials about the Bishop and about the so-called Cannon-Goldhurst case; " Carter Glass Denies Threat to Gold Standard." Article regarding differences of opinion between Carter Glass and Hoover administration Republicans, October 13, 1932, New York Times. Numerous other articles and editorials on the subject; Editorials regarding controversy between Carter Glass and Secretary of Treasury Mills prior to national election, undated; Reports of Carter Glass' denouncement of Edwin R. Seligman's story that Paul M. Warburg was responsible for the reserve and note issue provisions of the Federal Reserve Act, 1927; Published letter from Carter Glass on the matter; Perhaps one hundred or more editorials and comments concerning the political activities of Bishop James Cannon, the Senate's inquiry into the disposition of money contributed to him for use in political campaigns, etc.; Many editorials regarding Bishop Cannon's fight for prohibition and accounts of attempts to make him a martyr, mostly undated, but appears to have been during and after the Bishop's anti-Smith campaign in 1928; Accounts of Carter Glass' attack of a book by Professor Seymour of Yale in which the latter implied that Colonel House was responsible for the Federal Reserve Act; Many editorial comments on the controversy between Carter Glass an House (ca. 1927); Many articles and editorials concerning Carter Glass' position in the 1936 Presidential election and speeches made by him assailing some New Deal policies, especially a controversial speech made in Ashland at Randolph Macon College; Editorials regarding the possibility and probability of Carter Glass for Democratic presidential nominee in the 1924 election. There are probably upwards of 100 such units, some of which speculate heavily on the outcome of the convention. McAdoo also mentioned often; New York Timesarticle reviewing first ten months of Harding's administration, dated 1922; Miscellaneous clippings having to do with alleged local political manipulation by certain people and of various other subjects. The number of articles on any one of these subjects is small; Sports articles, medical articles and those of a religious nature; Newspaper coverage of a speech by Carter Glass in Atlanta at the National Association of Credit Men, undated; Speech included praises of farm credit legislation and advice to farmers; Account of Carter Glass speech to Masons Convention in which he attacked attempts to lower the bars of immigration, undated; Editorials regarding the ratification of a peace treaty with Germany. Much attention given to the part "former President Woodrow Wilson " will play in the affair, undated; About 10 or 15 accounts of a great tribute paid to "former President Woodrow Wilson " on the fifth anniversary of the armistice signing.
